episodeTitle: A Big Rice Cake Tossing Race at the Castle! Red Nose's Plot!
episodeTitleJapanese: お城で餅まき大レース！赤い鼻の陰謀
episodeTitleRomanized: Oshiro de mochi maki dai rēsu! Akai hana no inbō
description: In Grand Jipangu's Edo-period setting, the Great Mochimaki Festival is underway where townspeople compete to catch rice cakes thrown from the shogun's castle. One mochimaki contains a valuable diamond worth 10,000,000 rio berry. Buggy and his crew plot to steal the treasure, eventually taking Princess Vivi hostage. Detective Luffy intervenes to save the princess and thwart Buggy's plans. Zoro ultimately catches the prized mochimaki but discards it.

openingSong.title: Crazy Rainbow
openingSong.titleJapanese: クレイジーレインボー

events.title: Great Mochimaki Festival Begins
events.description: The annual Great Mochimaki Festival is underway in Grand Jipangu. Townspeople gather at the shogun's castle to participate in the traditional rice cake throwing event. One special mochimaki contains a diamond worth 10,000,000 rio berry.
events.significance: Establishes the setting and central event of this filler episode, introducing the Edo-period alternate reality version of the One Piece world.

events.title: Rice Cake Delivery Preparation
events.description: Nami (Onami), Sanji, and Chopper prepare to deliver a large quantity of rice cakes to be thrown from the shogun's castle during the Mochimaki Festival. The cakes must reach the castle safely for the festival to proceed.
events.significance: Sets up the main conflict as Buggy will attempt to intercept and steal these rice cakes, particularly the one containing the valuable diamond.

events.title: Buggy's Conspiracy Unfolds
events.description: Buggy the Clown and his henchmen devise multiple plans to seize the rice cakes before they reach the castle. Their primary goal is to obtain the mochimaki containing the valuable diamond worth 10,000,000 rio berry.
events.significance: Establishes Buggy as the antagonist of this episode and sets the central conflict in motion. This continues Buggy's role as a recurring villain in the Boss Luffy Historical Special series.

events.title: Buggy's First Heist Attempts Fail
events.description: Buggy and his crew make several attempts to intercept and steal the rice cakes during their delivery to the castle. Despite their various schemes and plans, each attempt is thwarted by the delivery team and other circumstances.
events.significance: Shows the comedic nature of this filler arc as Buggy's plans repeatedly fail, maintaining the lighthearted tone of the Boss Luffy Historical Special.

events.title: Buggy Takes Princess Vivi Hostage
events.description: After his previous plans fail, Buggy resorts to taking Princess Vivi, the shogun's daughter, hostage in a desperate attempt to obtain the valuable mochimaki and the diamond inside.
events.significance: Escalates the conflict to a more serious situation, requiring Detective Luffy's intervention. This demonstrates Buggy's willingness to use underhanded tactics even in this alternate universe setting.

events.title: Luffy Uses a Jutte Weapon
events.description: Detective Luffy arrives to rescue Princess Vivi and confronts Buggy. In a rare moment for the character, Luffy wields a small jutte (a traditional Japanese weapon used by Edo-period police), though he primarily just holds it while punching as usual.
events.significance: This is one of the only episodes in the entire One Piece anime where Luffy uses a weapon, making it a notable and unique moment. The jutte fits his role as a detective in this historical special.

events.title: Luffy Defeats Buggy and Rescues Vivi
events.description: Detective Luffy successfully defeats Buggy and his crew, thwarting their conspiracy to steal the valuable mochimaki. Princess Vivi is rescued safely and the rice cakes are secured for the festival.
events.significance: Resolves the main conflict of the episode, with Luffy once again proving victorious over Buggy. Continues the pattern of Luffy defeating Buggy that runs throughout the series.

events.title: The Mochimaki Festival Concludes Successfully
events.description: With Buggy defeated and the rice cakes safe, the Mochimaki Festival proceeds as planned. The rice cakes are thrown from the castle to the gathered townspeople below, who scramble to catch them.
events.significance: Allows the cultural celebration to proceed as intended, showing the success of Luffy and his friends in protecting the festival tradition.

events.title: Zoro Catches and Discards the Prized Mochimaki
events.description: During the rice cake tossing, Zoro manages to catch the special mochimaki containing the diamond worth 10,000,000 rio berry. However, true to his character, Zoro shows no interest in the treasure and simply throws it away.
events.significance: Demonstrates Zoro's character consistency even in this alternate universe setting - he values personal strength and honor over material wealth. Provides a comedic and ironic ending to the treasure hunt that drove the episode's conflict.

events.title: Festival Feast and Celebration
events.description: The episode concludes with everyone enjoying the mochimaki and celebrating the successful festival. The townspeople and main characters eat until they are satisfied, enjoying the fruits of their efforts to protect the celebration.
events.significance: Provides a peaceful and satisfying conclusion to the filler episode, emphasizing themes of community, celebration, and shared joy that are common in One Piece.

themes.description: The episode showcases the Mochimaki Festival, a traditional Japanese New Year celebration adapted into the One Piece world. The importance of preserving cultural events and community traditions is central to the story.
themes.symbolism: The rice cakes represent shared prosperity and good fortune for the new year, while Buggy's attempt to steal them represents greed threatening communal celebration.
culturalReferences: Mochimaki is a real Japanese tradition where rice cakes are thrown from buildings during festivals and celebrations, particularly around New Year's Day (which this episode references as the seventh day of the new year).
The jutte weapon Luffy uses was historically carried by Edo-period doshin (police officers), fitting his role as Detective Luffy.
The Edo-period setting references Japan's historical period from 1603-1868, known for its cultural development and isolationist policies.

themes.description: Detective Luffy's role as protector of the townspeople and Princess Vivi demonstrates his commitment to justice and helping others, even in this alternate universe.
themes.symbolism: The jutte represents law enforcement authority, while Luffy's use of it (but still primarily fighting with his fists) shows that his core character - relying on personal strength and determination - remains constant.

themes.description: Zoro's decision to discard the valuable diamond-filled mochimaki emphasizes that true worth isn't found in material possessions.
themes.symbolism: The discarded diamond represents the idea that personal honor and principles are worth more than money - a value consistent with Zoro's character throughout the series.

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy fills his role as Detective Luffy (or Boss Luffy) in the Edo-period setting, protecting townspeople and upholding justice. Notably uses a jutte weapon, which is extremely rare for his character.
keyActions: Responds to the crisis when Princess Vivi is taken hostage
Uses a small jutte weapon while confronting Buggy
Defeats Buggy and rescues Princess Vivi
Ensures the Mochimaki Festival can proceed successfully

characterSpotlights.development: Buggy serves as the main antagonist, plotting to steal the valuable mochimaki. His schemes become increasingly desperate, culminating in taking Princess Vivi hostage.
keyActions: Devises multiple plans to steal the rice cakes
Makes several failed attempts to intercept the delivery
Takes Princess Vivi hostage as a last resort

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro participates in the festival and ultimately catches the prized mochimaki, but his disinterest in material wealth leads him to discard it.
keyActions: Successfully catches the mochimaki containing the 10,000,000 rio berry diamond
Throws away the valuable prize, showing his values transcend material wealth

characterSpotlights.development: As Onami, Nami works with Sanji at The Pinwheel restaurant and is involved in delivering rice cakes for the festival.
keyActions: Helps prepare rice cakes for the festival
Participates in delivering the cakes to the shogun's castle

characterSpotlights.development: Vivi appears as the shogun's daughter in this alternate universe, becoming Buggy's hostage before being rescued by Luffy.

mangaDifferences.difference: This entire episode is anime-original filler content that does not appear in the manga. The Boss Luffy Historical Special is a standalone alternate universe story created specifically for the anime.
The episode aired during a critical moment in the Enies Lobby Arc (between episodes 291 and 293), interrupting the canon storyline when Chopper was rampaging in Monster Point form.

trivia.fact: This is one of the only episodes in the entire One Piece anime where Luffy uses a weapon - specifically a small jutte (a traditional Japanese police weapon from the Edo period).
The episode achieved a TV rating of 6.2% in Japan, ranking #5 for its time slot.
On Hatchan's forehead in this episode, the character 寿 (longevity/congratulations) appears instead of his typical Sun Pirates mark, fitting the New Year festival theme.
The episode has an IMDb rating of 5.7/10 based on 974 votes, making it one of the lower-rated One Piece episodes.
The episode aired exactly one week after Episode 291, continuing the Boss Luffy Historical Special that had been introduced in that episode and in Special Episode 4.

sources.title: Boss Luffy Historical Special - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: Zoro ultimately obtains the prized mochimaki containing a diamond worth 10,000,000 rio berry but throws it away, staying true to his character's disinterest in material wealth.
Crazy Rainbow by Tackey and Tsubasa was used as the opening theme. The duo were actually animated into Episode 303 (another Boss Luffy episode) to celebrate April Fool's Day 2007.
This episode had no ending theme song. One Piece stopped using ending themes from episode 279 to episode 1070 when the show's timeslot changed from Sunday evening to Sunday morning in October 2006.

sources.title: Why did One Piece stop having ending songs? - Anime StackExchange
